title: "Symbolism of the Elements and Transformation"
first_phrase: In the previous part, we learned about the various phases of the circulation and transformation process and the symbolism of the elements. In this last section, we delve deeper into the unconscious symbolism of the elements, specifically how they appear in nonverbal communication. The scholar Calbris notes that the classic symbols of the elements also correspond to a broader worldview accessible even at the cenesthetic level. We also learn about the teachings of Giuliano Kremmerz and Evola and their use of the subtle bodies to interpret the classic elements.
content: Simbolismo espanso Questo simbolismo corrisponde ad una piú ampia visione del mondo che può essere acceduta a livello cenestesico anche in un modo piú sottile, “sentendo” le differenti densità nel proprio corpo. Il diagramma qui sotto porta una corrispondenza ed una interpretazione degli elementi classici, che segue gli insegnamenti di Giuliano Kremmerz ed Evola e utilizza i corpi sottili - Secondo l’enunciato “tutto ciò che ha il gran mondo, anche l’uomo lo possiede” , Solfo, Mercurio e Sale sono nell’universo – il “trimundio” – e sono nell’uomo, e nell’uomo i “tre mondi” si manifestano come Anima, Spirito e Corpo. [. . .]
last_phrase: In conclusion, the expanded symbolism presented here offers a unique way of understanding the world and oneself. By tapping into the cenesthetic level, one can "feel" the different densities in their body and access the trimundio of sulfur, mercury, and salt within themselves. This leads to the manifestation of the three worlds of the soul, spirit, and body, each represented by symbolic elements, astrological symbols, and alchemic principles. Overall, this holistic approach provides a practical framework for spiritual development and self-discovery.
